text: in this video you'll see how to
configure an emr cluster in aws service
catalog
and launch it using amazon emr studio
with this integration you can deploy
pre-defined templates to enforce best
practices
simplify the emr deployment process and
improve budget adherence and cost
control
this is emr studio an integrated
development environment
or ide that makes it easy for data
scientists and data engineers to develop
visualize and debug applications written
in r python
scala and pi spark let's start from the
perspective of a data engineer and
create a new workspace
a workspace is a collection of one or
more notebooks for a project
for this example we already have an
amazon simple storage service or amazon
s3 bucket where our notebooks will be
saved
workspaces can be created without an emr
cluster or provisioned alongside a new
or existing emr cluster in your account
we'll continue without specifying an emr
cluster
the workspace is now ready when we click
it it opens in a hosted ide
powered by jupiter lab emr studio
automatically creates an empty notebook
for the workspace
let's take a look at the options in our
sidebar tabs
we can choose to open initialize or
clone a git repository for collaboration
we can attach existing emr clusters to
perform emr workloads or provision a new
emr cluster with specific parameters
we can link our workspace with up to
three git repositories for easy access
and synchronization
we can also set various settings and
preferences for jupiter lab
returning to the cluster options we can
see that no clusters are available to
attach to this workspace
to simplify the emr deployment process
emr administrators can create service
catalog products that enable quick
provisioning of emr instances in emr
studio
let's switch to the perspective of an
emr administrator with administrator
access to service catalog
the service catalog portfolio named emr
studio developers stack
contains the emr products we're allowing
emr studio end users to provision
through the jupiter lab development
environment
this portfolio has products for two
versions of aws emr
for a product to be accessible to the
emr studio end user it must be
associated with this portfolio
which has been configured with the
necessary service roles and permissions
these roles and permissions are required
for us to view the service catalog
products in emr studio let's look at the
cloud formation template for one of
these products
this product has one version currently a
product can be updated by creating new
versions
with new configurations and properties
tailored to the aws service it concerns
let's take a quick look at the template
for this version
the template defines a pre-configured
emr cluster and allows the user to
choose between a range of allowed values
for the instance count and emr version
administrators can choose any number of
different properties to expose to end
users or hold constant let's upload a
new service catalog product that defines
an emr cluster that can be provisioned
through emr studio
we'll provide a name and owner leaving
all other values as their default
our account contains an s3 bucket with
our custom service catalog product
cloudformation template
we can specify its url here we'll
specify a version name
now let's review the settings and create
the product
to make the product available to end
users through emr studio
we must now add it to the portfolio we
saw earlier
returning to the data engineers
perspective let's provision a new emr
cluster using the service catalog
template
here are the two emr products from the
service catalog portfolio
as well as the new product that was
associated with it let's provision a
cluster using the new product template
now let's switch back to the
administrator's perspective to ensure
that the provisioning conforms to our
expectations
the emr cluster provisioning has just
been requested by the data engineer
let's take a look at cloud formation
as you can see a new cloudformation
stack has begun creation
the stack corresponds to the new service
catalog provisioned product
we can see that a user initiated the
cluster let's take a look at aws emr
a new emr cluster is now listed let's
dig deeper
here we can monitor the exact status
history and details of the emr clusters
provisioned by end users through our
service catalog products
let's return to service catalog to see
how the cluster is reflected
notice the new provisioned product with
the status of under change
indicating an in-progress provisioning
status let's return to the data
engineer's perspective
our cluster is now finished provisioning
and is available to us to use in emr
workloads
let's attach the cluster
the workspace is ready for emr data
analysis workloads
to ensure that this is the case let's
quickly check the emr studio dashboard
our workspace has a status of attached
indicating that the emr cluster we just
provisioned
is successfully associated with the
workspace
